Selective epoxidation and allylic oxidation of cyclohexene were realized in the presence of BEA-Ti and (metallo)porphyrin catalysts. The integration of BEA-Ti and porphyrin H2MTPP afforded cyclohexene oxide with excellent selectivity (cyclohexene oxide/ 2-cyclohexen-1-one=85:15). BEA-Ti and metalloporphyrin MnMTPP yielded 2-cyclohexen-1-one with high selectivity (cyclohexene oxide/ 2-cyclohexen-1-one=12:88). Resulting active species involving of (metallo)porphyrin, TiIV sites and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) promoted the oxidation process of cyclohexene. A possible mechanism resulting in the formation cyclohexene oxide and 2-cyclohexen-1-one was proposed. The outer-sphere effect constructed by (metallo)porphyrin, TiIV sites and TBHP on the surface of BEA-Ti framework improved the epoxidation and allylic oxidation both in the conversion and selectivity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Epoxidation Allylic oxidation BEA-Ti Porphyrin Outer-sphere effect Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Oxidation reactions, such as C=C bond oxidations and allyl oxidation, played an important role in organic synthesis both in the laboratory and industrial processes [1–5]. In nature, these transformations could be realized in a selective manner when heme and non-heme iron-containing enzymes were involved in the oxidation reactions. Inspired by these natural enzymes, considerable efforts had been made to develop novel selective catalysts for these chemical transformations [6]. Among these catalysts, titanium silicalite zeolite-based catalysts displayed certain catalytic activity towards epoxidation reaction [7], such as tetrahedrally coordinated Ti active sites and framework topology. Notably, their catalytic performances were closely related to the inherent structure characteristics affected by the synthesis conditions of titanium silicalite zeolite [8,9]. Many researches focused more on the precise control of microenvironment of Ti active sites in the zeolite [10–13]. The distinct differences in the catalytic activity were observed when Ti active sites were located in different confinement environments of the same zeolite framework revealing the promoting effect of structural confinement in the mass transfer between the reactants and Ti active sites [12]. For example, Ti-beta displayed the weak ability to activate TBHP, which was ascribed to the difficult accommodation of small pores of Ti-beta for large transition state of Ti-OOtBu and bulky cycloalkene [14,15]. Herein, we hoped the cooperation of Ti-beta and (metallo)porphyrin could separately catalyze selective epoxidation and allylic oxidation of olefins. In addition, the silanol nests in the BEA framework showed obvious promotion effect in the catalytic activity of Ti active sites towards epoxidation. The maximum content of silanol nests in the framework displayed excellent catalytic activity than that free of defect sites [16]. A series of experimental and theoretical studies demonstrated that the delicate control of Ti active sites in suitable microenvironment would be crucial for the catalytic performance [17–20]. Confinement of Ti active sites within micropores has been proved to be an efficient approach to adjust their catalytic properties [21–24] through the noncovalent interactions of pore walls with reacting species in the inner-sphere of active site. Recent research about partially confining environments on the surfaces of zeolites similar with the surface pockets of enzymes [25,26], has received tremendous interests. Thus, a much wider range of reactions, involving intermediates and molecules that are too large to enter the inner-sphere of active sites, could be improved through the beneficial confinement effect of outer-sphere in the active sites. Generally, outer-sphere effects could be adjusted by surface moieties that were vicinal (noncoordinating) to the active centers [27–33]. Here, we demonstrated that the outer-sphere environments had a profound effect on the catalytic performance of TiIV sites supported on BEA framework. The oxidation of cyclohexene with TBHP was selected as the model reaction. Porphyrins and metal porphyrins were applied in the construction of microenvironment of TiIV active sites to realize the selective oxidation of cyclohexene. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Benzaldehyde, p-hydroxybenzaldehyde, propionic acid, pyrrole, methanol, acetonitrile, dichloromethane, anhydrous ethanol and other chemicals were reagent grade, which were provided by Aladdin Corp. (Shanghai, China). Cyclohexene, zirconium n-butoxide, hafnium n-butoxide, metal chloride were purchased from McLean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., (Shanghai, China). β zeolite, TBHP in decane and urea peroxide were supplied by Thain Chemical Technology Co., Ltd., (Shanghai, China). Concentrated nitric acid and 30% hydrogen peroxide were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company. 2.2 Preparation of 5-(4-Hydroxyphenyl)-10, 15, 20-triphenylporphyrin (H2MTPP) and its metalloporphyrin MnMTPP 4-Hydroxybenzaldehyde (3.675 g, 30 mmol), benzaldehyde (9.55 g, 90 mmol) and propionic acid (100 ml) were added into a three-necked bottle (500 mL). The reaction mixture was heated at 160 °C under vigorous stirring conditions until the solid reactant disappeared. Then, pyrrole (8 g, 120 mmol) dissolved in 60 ml propionic acid were dropped dropwise into the solution. After being heated to reflux for 90 min, the hot reaction solution was poured into a large amount of ethanol quickly. The resulting ethanol solution was transferred to the refrigerator for recrystallization. The precipitated solid was filtered and purified on a silica gel column with dichloromethane as eluent. The purple product was dried and stored in vacuum drying oven. H2MTPP and a certain amount of manganese chloride were dissolved in dimethyl formamide. After being heated to reflux for 4 h, the hot reaction solution was poured into a large amount of water. The resulting aqueous solution was extracted with dichloromethane. The metalloporphyrin MnMTPP and unreacted porphyrin were dissolved in dichloromethane phase, while unreacted metal chlorides were dissolved in the aqueous phase. After purification by silica gel column, resulting metalloporphyrin MnMTPP was dried and stored in vacuum drying oven. 2.3 Preparation of BEA-Ti zeolite For BEA-Ti, a modified liquid phase infiltration method was applied in the dealumination process. At first, dealumination process was conducted to create necessary vacant framework sites in the zeolite. Parent BEA zeolites (Si: Al = 12.5, NH4+ cation) were added into concentrated nitric acid. After being heated to reflux for 20 h, the resulting dealuminated BEA zeolites were washed with concentrated nitric acid and deionized water. After drying at 100 °C, the obtained solid was calcined at 550 °C for 6 h, affording dealuminated Si-β zeolite (Si: Al > 1200). Then, the resulting dealuminated BEA was dispersed in dichloromethane in nitrogen atmosphere. A certain amount of TiCl4 was added into the suspension. The introduction of Ti ions into the framework of dealuminated BEA was conducted at 50 °C for 3 h. BEA-Ti with different Ti contents could be prepared by adjusting the amount of TiCl4. It should be noticed that TiCl4 could easily react with water in the air to form toxic HCl gas. Thus, TiCl4 should be added carefully under inert gas protection. After the reaction, dichloromethane was removed under vacuum. The obtained solid was calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. The resulting white BEA-Ti powder was stored in the vacuum oven. 2.4 Synthesis of BEA-Ti-H2MTPP and BEA-Ti-MnMTPP The prepared BEA-Ti zeolite was added into the toluene solution containing porphyrin H2MTPP or metalloporphyrin MnMTPP. The preparation process was monitored by TLC. Once no porphyrin H2MTPP or metalloporphyrin MnMTPP was detected in the reaction mixture, the reaction was terminated. After being stirred at 80 °C for 10 h, no porphyrin H2MTPP or metalloporphyrin MnMTPP was detected. Meanwhile, the suspension changed from color purple to green. After reaction, the green solid was obtained through filtration and washing. Then, the resulting BEA-Ti-H2MTPP and BEA-Ti-MnMTPP was dried in vacuum oven and stored for use. 2.5 Characterization of catalyst The structure of porphyrin and corresponding metalloporphyrin could be confirmed by NMR. The content of Ti in BEA-Ti was determined by ICP-OES (PerkinElmer 8300). The crystal phase of the sample was determined by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) (Bruker D8 Advance, Cu Kα). The hydrogen and silicon spectra of BEA-Ti were determined by solid state nuclear magnetic resonance (Agilent 600M). Attenuated total reflection infrared spectroscopy of BEA-Ti in KBr pellets were recorded using Bruker Tensor [27] spectrometer to determine the formed bonds of Ti in BEA skeleton. 2.6 Catalytic experiment 2.6.1 Typical procedure for the selective oxidation of cyclohexene by BEA-Ti-H2MTPP or BEA-Ti-MnMTPP The catalytic experiments for epoxides were carried out in a 15 ml pressure tube. In the tube, BEA-Ti-H2MTPP was dispersed in acetonitrile solution (2 mL) containing cyclohexene (0.13 g). The mass ratio of BEA-Ti-H2MTPP to cyclohexene was 20:100. The mass content of Ti in the catalyst (BEA-Ti-H2MTPP) was 10 mg/Kg. The molar ratio of Ti to H2MTPP was 2:1. Then, a certain amount of TBHP was added into the solution. The molar ratio of TBHP to cyclohexene was 2:1. After stirring and heating at 60 °C for 16 h, the mixture was cooled to room temperature. The organic phase was analyzed by gas chromatography with DB-WAX column. The catalytic experiments for 2-cyclohexen-1-one were carried out in a 15 ml pressure tube. In the tube, BEA-Ti-MnMTPP was dispersed in acetonitrile solution (2 mL) containing cyclohexene (0.13 g). The mass ratio of BEA-Ti-MnMTPP to cyclohexene was 15:100. The mass content of Ti in the catalyst (BEA-Ti-MnMTPP) was 25 mg/Kg. The molar ratio of Ti to MnMTPP was 2:1. Then, a certain amount of TBHP was added into the solution. The molar ratio of TBHP to cyclohexene was 2:1. After stirring and heating at 60 °C for 16 h, the mixture was cooled to room temperature. The organic phase was analyzed by gas chromatography with DB-WAX column. 2.6.2 Procedure for the selective oxidation of cyclohexene by adding BEA-Ti and H2MTPP (MnMTPP) separately The catalytic experiments for epoxides were carried out in a 15 ml pressure tube. In the tube, BEA-Ti and H2MTPP were dispersed in acetonitrile solution (2 mL) containing cyclohexene (0.13 g). The total mass of BEA-Ti and H2MTPP held 20 percent of mass of cyclohexene. The mass content of Ti in BEA-Ti was 10 mg/Kg. The molar ratio of Ti to H2MTPP was 2:1. Then, a certain amount of TBHP was added into the solution. The molar ratio of TBHP to cyclohexene was 2:1. After stirring and heating at 60 °C for 16 h, the mixture was cooled to room temperature. The organic phase was analyzed by gas chromatography with DB-WAX column. The catalytic experiments for 2-cyclohexen-1-one were carried out in a 15 ml pressure tube. In the tube, BEA-Ti and MnMTPP were dispersed in acetonitrile solution (2 mL) containing cyclohexene (0.13 g). The total mass of BEA-Ti and MnMTPP held 15 percent of mass of cyclohexene. The mass content of Ti in BEA-Ti was 25 mg/Kg. The molar ratio of Ti to MnMTPP was 2:1. Then, a certain amount of TBHP was added into the solution. The molar ratio of TBHP to cyclohexene was 2:1. After stirring and heating at 60 °C for 16 h, the mixture was cooled to room temperature. The organic phase was analyzed by gas chromatography with DB-WAX column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization To verify the stability of BEA zeolites in the dealumination and metal-doping process, the structures of the as-prepared dealuminated BEA (Si-β) and BEA-Ti were characterized by XRD. As shown in Fig. 1 A, XRD patterns of dealuminated BEA and BEA-Ti was consistent with that in BEA, demonstrating that resulting zeolites still maintained the integrity of BEA framework after dealumination and metal-doping process [34]. To further confirm the doping situation of Ti atoms, attenuated total reflection infrared spectroscopy of BEA, Si-β and BEA-Ti were performed (Fig. 1B). Three characteristic absorption peaks were observed in the above three samples. The peaks at 1234, 1095, and 805 cm-1 belonged to the inner tetrahedral stretching of SiO4, the Vas(Si-O), and the Vs(Si-O), respectively [34]. A new weak absorption peak at 960 cm-1 was detected in BEA-Ti compared with BEA and Si-β [35]. This peak corresponded to the stretching vibration of Si-O-Ti, demonstrating that Ti atoms were incorporated into the framework of BEA. Fig. 2 A displayed the 1H MAS NMR spectrum of BEA, Si-β and BEA-Ti. In the 1H MAS NMR spectrum of BEA framework, the peaks at 0.89 ppm corresponded to protons of isolated and/or terminal SiO-H. The signals observed at 3.40 pm and 3.86 ppm were due to protons of bridged Si-O(H)-Al Brønsted groups or H-bonded silanol groups at vacant T-atom sites [36,37]. The 1H MAS NMR signal at 6.59 ppm could be explained by the water adsorption on the Lewis acid site of the zeolite framework [38]. Due to the removal of Al atoms and formation of vacant T-atom sites related to SiO-H groups, two signals at 3.40 pm and 3.86 ppm appeared a right shift. Sharper peaks were displayed in the 1H MAS NMR spectrum of Si-β. The appearance of the characteristic peak at 4.09 ppm evidenced the reaction of TiCl4 with H-bonded SiO-H groups. The decrease in the peak intensity at 0.89 ppm further confirmed the introduction of Ti into BEA zeolite by reacting with isolated SiO-H groups [37]. Generally, there were three kinds of Si atoms in the BEA framework. Si atoms in the Si(OSi)4 environment represented at -116.3 ppm. Si atoms in the Si(OH)(OSi)3 environment displayed at -107.6 ppm. Furthermore, few Si atoms in the Si(OH)2(OSi)2 environment was also proved by the weak peak at -97.8 ppm. In the spectrum of Si-β, the peak at -107.2 ppm corresponding to the Si atoms in the Si(OH)(OSi)3 environment showed a strong increase in the intensity due to the removal of Al atoms from BEA zeolite [37]. In the spectrum of BEA-Ti, the characteristic peak at -106.8 ppm belonged to the Si atom in Si(OH)(OSi)3. The peak at -116.3 ppm (Fig. 2B) represented the Si atom in Si(OM)4 (M= Si, Ti). After incorporating Ti ions in the Si-β, a smaller peak located at 106.8 ppm was observed. The right shift and decreased intensity further confirmed the reaction between TiCl4 and silanol groups [39]. Fig. 3 A showed that the Mn-N characteristic vibration of MnMTPP was around 1010 cm-1, indicating that the metal cation was coordinated in the porphyrin ring. In BEA-Ti, the peaks of 1050-1225 cm-1 could be attributed to asymmetric stretch of T-O bond [40]. The mixed catalyst (BEA-Ti+H2MTPP) retained the special absorption peaks of BEA-Ti and H2MTPP. Similarly, another mixed catalyst (BEA-Ti+MnMTPP) retained the special absorption peaks of BEA-Ti and MnMTPP. But in BEA-Ti-H2MTPP or BEA-Ti-MnMTPP, a strong peak at 576 cm-1 referring to v[Ti(O2)], appeared simultaneously [41]. Additional peaks observed at 1630 and 3422 cm-1 were related to lattice water molecules and surface hydroxylic groups, indicating that the bond between BEA-Ti and H2MTPP/ MnMTPP were accompanied by the disruption of hydrogen-bonded of H2O molecules at the adsorption sites and the hydroxyl groups [42,43]. UV-vis spectroscopy could be used to characterize the coordination state of titanium species in titanium-containing zeolites. In Fig. 3B, there was a strong asymmetric peak at about 225 nm, which could be attributed to an oxygen-tetrahedral Ti(IV) coordination compound. And the peaks at 275 and 278 nm were assigned to dimers/oligomers of extra framework Ti species [40,44,45]. When BEA-Ti was coordinated with hydroxyl groups in H2MTPP or MnMTPP, a right shift was observed. Compared to pure BEA-Ti, BEA-Ti-H2MTPP showed obvious B-band and Q-band absorption peaks of porphyrin at around 427 nm and 665 nm [46]. In addition, BEA-Ti-MnMTPP revealed CT-band, Q-band and Soret band absorption peaks of MnMTPP at 413 nm, 475 nm, 570 nm, respectively. These results proved that Ti atoms in BEA-Ti was coordinated with the hydroxyl group in H2MTPP or MnMTPP. 3.2 Catalytic performance of different catalysts Initially, BEA-Ti-H2MTPP or BEA-Ti-MnMTPP catalysts were evaluated in the oxidation of cyclohexene. Two interesting phenomena existed in the oxidation process. Firstly, obvious differences in the selectivity were detected when BEA-Ti-H2MTPP or BEA-Ti-MnMTPP was applied in the oxidation of cyclohexene. The combination of BEA-Ti-H2MTPP porphyrin afforded cyclohexene oxide with high selectivity, while the integration of BEA-Ti-MnMTPP yielded 2-cyclohexen-1-one with high selectivity (Fig. 4 ). In the preparation of BEA-Ti-H2MTPP or BEA-Ti-MnMTPP, the coordination of BEA-Ti with purple porphyrin or metal porphyrin (Fig. S3A) afforded a green catalyst (BEA-Ti-H2MTPP or BEA-Ti-MnMTPP) (Fig. S3B). In addition, the color of reaction solution changed upon the addition of TBHP. When the green catalyst (BEA-Ti-H2MTPP or BEA-Ti-MnMTPP) was added into the acetonitrile solution, a solid-liquid mixture containing green solution was obtained (Fig. S3C). Interestingly, addition of TBHP into the reaction mixture resulted in a solid-liquid mixture containing purple solution (Fig. S3D). Thus, the change in the color of the solution demonstrated the linkage between (metal) porphyrin and BEA-Ti might be destroyed after the addition of TBHP. To confirm this hypothesis, BEA-Ti and H2MTPP were added into acetonitrile solution containing TBHP and cyclohexene, yielding a mixture similar with that in Fig. S3D. After reacting at 60 °C for 16 h, the ratio between cyclohexene oxide and 2-cyclohexen-1-one was 78:22. Similarly, BEA-Ti and MnMTPP promoted allylic oxidation of cyclohexene, affording 2-cyclohexen-1-one with excellent selectivity. The ratio between cyclohexene oxide and 2-cyclohexen-1-one was 12:88. Similar results were obtained when BEA-Ti and H2MTPP (MnMTPP) were added separately into the reaction solution without the coordination between TiIV sites in the BEA-Ti framework and phenolic hydroxyl group in the H2MTPP (MnMTPP). Thus, coordinated catalysts (BEA-Ti-H2MTPP or BEA-Ti-MnMTPP) were not used in the subsequent optimization process of epoxidation and allylic oxidation. On the contrary, BEA-Ti and H2MTPP (MnMTPP) were added separately. 3.3 Selective epoxidation catalyzed by BEA-Ti and porphyrin H2MTPP The reaction data of selective oxidation catalyzed BEA-Ti and porphyrin catalysts and the carbon balance yield calculated by dividing the total yields of the oxidation products (cyclohexene oxide and 2-cyclohexen-1-one) by the conversion of cyclohexene were listed in Table 1 . Initially, the amount of oxidant was evaluated. When the molar ratio between cyclohexene and TBHP was 1:2, the yield and selectivity of product reached the best. More TBHP would lead to a decrease in the selectivity [47]. When the amount of catalyst was set to be 11%, the yield of epoxides was 54.0% (Table 1, entry 5). Further increase in the amount of catalyst did not change the yield and selectivity significantly (Table 1, entry 8). When the temperature was increased from 50 °C to 60 °C, the conversion increased significantly, affording a conversion of 42.8 %. The ratio between cyclohexene oxide and 2-cyclohexen-1-one was 86:14 (Table 1, entry 2). Higher temperature went against the conversion of cyclohexene (Table 1, entry 3). A slight fluctuation was observed in the selectivity for cyclohexene oxides with the increase in the reaction temperature mainly due to the decomposition of partial TBHP [48]. In addition, the yield increased significantly when the reaction time was increased from 6 h to 16 h, yielding a conversion of 74%. Extended reaction time resulted in decreased selectivity. When the reaction was set to 16 h, the yield of epoxides was 54.0% and the carbon balance was 93.4%. Enough reaction time was necessary for the epoxidation reaction. However, a series of side reaction would be occurred with increased reaction time in view of the instability of epoxides [49]. The decomposition of partial TBHP resulted in a slight fluctuation in the conversion of cyclohexene [48]. In the control experiment, single BEA-Ti was also applied in the oxidation of cyclohexene. Of course, single H2MTPP displayed no catalytic activity for epoxidation (Fig. 5 A). On the contrary, a yield of 15.6% for 2-cyclohexen-1-one was detected when H2MTPP was used as the catalyst. A combination of 2-cyclohexen-1-one and cyclohexene oxide were observed when BEA-Ti was applied in the oxidation of cyclohexene. The ratio between cyclohexene oxide and 2-cyclohexen-1-one was 49:51 (Fig. 5A). Amazingly, more epoxides were formed when BEA-Ti met with H2MTPP porphyrin catalyst. The selectivity for epoxides increased from 49:51 to 78:22. Above results revealed that BEA-Ti and porphyrin catalysts acted synergistically in the oxidation of cyclohexene. The introduction of porphyrin catalysts improved the selectivity for epoxidation. Thus, the ratio of BEA-Ti to porphyrin was also one important issue that needed to be considered. When the ratio of BEA-Ti to porphyrin was 2:1, a significant increase in the selectivity was obtained. An excellent selectivity of 81:19 was detected (Fig. 5B). BEA-Ti with different contents of Ti were prepared based on the experimental procedure described in the experimental section. The contents of Ti in these catalysts were determined based on standard curve (t2) and displayed in Table S1. The effect of Ti content in BEA-Ti on the selectivity for epoxides was studied. The average values of the yields would be obtained through three parallel experiments. The experimental errors between three parallel experiments were below ±2%. Initially, the increase in the content of Ti yielded an obvious increase in the selectivity. When the content of Ti was 10 mg/Kg, an excellent selectivity (85:15) for epoxides was obtained, affording a yield of 74.7% (Fig. 5C). Further increase in the content of Ti resulted in a slight decrease in the selectivity. 3.4 Selective allylic oxidation catalyzed by BEA-Ti and metalloporphyrin MnMTPP As revealed in the previous section, allylic oxidation of cyclohexene could be realized when BEA-Ti and metalloporphyrin were used as the catalyst. Different metalloporphyrins were evaluated to investigate the effect of metalloporphyrins on the catalytic performance. Among the four metalloporphyrins, the combination of manganese porphyrin and BEA-Ti displayed the best catalytic activity towards the allylic oxidation of cyclohexene (Fig. 6 A), affording 2-cyclohexen-1-one with excellent selectivity. The reaction data of selective oxidation catalyzed BEA-Ti and metalloporphyrin MnMTPP catalysts and the carbon balance yield calculated by dividing the total yields of the oxidation products (2-cyclohexen-1-one and cyclohexene oxide) by the conversion of cyclohexene were listed in Table 2 . When the reaction time was increased from 4 h to 16 h, the yield of 2-cyclohexen-1-one increased from 53.9% to 69.0% (Table 2, entry 4 and 6). Further increase in the reaction time resulted in a slight decrease in the yield (Table 2, entry 7) with the decrease of conversion of cyclohexene due to decomposition of oxidants. It was worth noting that the highest field of 69.0 % could be obtained when the reaction time was 16 h, and the selectivity could be 89:11 (2-cyclohexen-1-one: cyclohexene oxide) (Table 2, entry 6). It was found that in the first 4 h, the selectivity of 2-cyclohexen-1-one could up close to 100%. In addition, when the reaction temperature was increased from 20 °C to 30 °C, the yield could reach 60.7% with a selectivity of 86:14. However, a downward trend was observed with further increase in temperature [50]. It was clearly that the yield of 2-cyclohexen-1-one reached 71.1 % and the carbon balance was 100% when the amount of catalyst was 15 % (Table 2, entry 8). And when the amount of catalyst was further increased, the yield and selectivity of the catalyst remained constant. When the molar ration of TBHP and cyclohexene was set to be 2:1, the yield of 2-cyclohexen-1-one could reach up to 71.1% with a selectivity of 88:12. Different from the trend in the epoxidation, no decrease in the selectivity was detected when more TBHP was added into the reaction mixture. Relatively higher stability of 2-cyclohexen-1-one under these conditions might be the cause for this phenomenon compared with cyclohexene oxide. With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, the content of Ti and metalloporphyrin on the allylic oxidation of cyclohexene catalyzed by BEA-Ti and MnMTPP catalysts was investigated. Mn-porphyrin could activate TBHP to oxidize alkene [51], and more MnMTPP promoted the improvement in the selectivity for 2-cyclohexen-1-one. When the ratio of BEA-Ti to MnMTPP was set to 2:1, the yield and selectivity for 2-cyclohexen-1-one were 69.0% and 88.0%, respectively (Fig. 6B). When the content of Ti was less than 25 mg/Kg, the yield and selectivity of 2-cyclohexen-1-one gradually increased with the increase in the content of Ti (Fig. 6C). A constant selectivity was observed with higher content of Ti. 3.5 Reaction mechanism Ti-beta zeolites showed a high activity for the epoxidation of cyclohexene, and the selectivity of the epoxide depended on the synthesis conditions of Ti-beta zeolites [8,9]. Specifically in our trials, BEA-Ti yielded a mixture of epoxides and 2-cyclohexen-1-one with a ratio of 50:50. The addition of MnMTPP into the reaction mixture accelerated the allylic oxidation [51], promoting the improvement in the yield of 2-cyclohexen-1-one (Fig. 4). Correspondingly, the epoxidation of cyclohexene was weakened [52]. On the contrary, the introduction of H2MTPP catalysts accelerated the formation of epoxides, weakening the allylic oxidation of cyclohexene. In other words, metal-coordinated or uncoordinated porphyrins would work with BEA-Ti in the oxidation of cyclohexene, resulting in different oxidation products. In the epoxidation reaction catalyzed by TS-1, the addition of H2O2 promoted the formation of silanol functionality through the cleavage Ti-OSi bonds in the zeolite [53]. Similarly, the cleavage of Ti-OSi would also be occurred upon TBHP bonding to TiIV, instead of the cleavage of porphyrin(O)-Ti. The change in the color of reaction solution (Fig. S3C and S3D) confirmed that the dissociation of H2MTPP (MnMTPP) and BEA-Ti occurred upon the addition of TBHP. Resulting active species could be stabilized through interaction with the walls of the pockets in the zeolite, yielding a sub-nanometer cavity. The interaction between calixarene and TiIV revealed by experimental and calculation based on density functional theory also confirmed this hypothesis [27,20]. When BEA-Ti-H2MTPP met with TBHP, active species generated through the cleavage of Ti-OSi and coordination with TBHP could react with cyclohexene in the assistance of cooperating silanol [20], affording cyclohexene oxide. When BEA-Ti-MnMTPP was used in the oxidation reaction, resulting active species including MnMTPP, TiIV sites and TBHP could react with cyclohexene, yielding 2-cyclohexen-1-one (Fig. 7 ). In the oxidation of cyclohexene catalyzed by BEA-Ti-H2MTPP, free radical scavengers displayed no obvious influence on the yield. In addition, the allylic oxidation reaction of cyclohexene was not inhibited when radical scavengers for hydroxyl radical, peroxy radical and alkoxy radical were added into the reaction mixture, demonstrating that a free radical mechanism mediated by MnMTPP [54] was not involved in this allylic oxidation reaction. 4 Conclusions The selective oxidation of cyclohexene was realized through the adjustment in the partner of BEA-Ti zeolite. When porphyrin H2MTPP was used in the oxidation, cyclohexene oxide was the main product. Metalloporphyrin MnMTPP promoted the formation of 2-cyclohexen-1-one with high selectivity. The transfer of oxygen atoms in the active species generated through the coordination between H2MTPP, TiIV sites and TBHP was the possible reaction mechanism for epoxidation. Free radical capture experiment indicated that non-radical route was the dominant position rather than free radical route mediated by MnMTPP. coredata.dc:description: Selective epoxidation and allylic oxidation of cyclohexene were realized in the presence of BEA-Ti and (metallo)porphyrin catalysts. The integration of BEA-Ti and porphyrin H2MTPP afforded cyclohexene oxide with excellent selectivity (cyclohexene oxide/ 2-cyclohexen-1-one=85:15). BEA-Ti and metalloporphyrin MnMTPP yielded 2-cyclohexen-1-one with high selectivity (cyclohexene oxide/ 2-cyclohexen-1-one=12:88). Resulting active species involving of (metallo)porphyrin, TiIV sites and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) promoted the oxidation process of cyclohexene. A possible mechanism resulting in the formation cyclohexene oxide and 2-cyclohexen-1-one was proposed. The outer-sphere effect constructed by (metallo)porphyrin, TiIV sites and TBHP on the surface of BEA-Ti framework improved the epoxidation and allylic oxidation both in the conversion and selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Selective epoxidation and allylic oxidation of olefins catalyzed by BEA-Ti and porphyrin catalysts
